This is one thing that you need to understand. posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
If it doesn't have a viable Terrifying Rage (and i am almost sure than in Arelith it doesn't) then it is not a true Barbarian. And a two-handed weapon in a PW that does not have WoG's Shield Bracers OR Sinfar's modifications to shield-less AC and also forbids you too take RDD that would boost your mediocre armour is a recipe that would cause more troubles than would solve, maybe it's nice to fantasize that you are playing CONAN but when you see it work in real gameplay you might get disappointed. Of course anything can be viable and even powerful with superior play but that's not why we are here, in fact it's the opposite of that in a sense. Anyway, point is that if Arelith doesn't have something distinct for Barbarians, then play a Weapon Master and you will have ten times the power and the fun. If you are gonna have low Ac then make a point to kill them as fast as possible before they can inflict serious damage to you.

And nothing is too difficult once you set your mind to it, Max can guide you through the whole process of building a character and before you know it, you will have your own Barbarian build ready to go. We taught another member to do that recently (Stagmeister) when he build Mazzy.

posts.author: Maximillian Kane
posts.content:
Hey Val, thanks for the backup.

Jaquerez, let's get started, shall we? Val is right, if Arelth doesn't have a way to compensate for the low Armor Class that a 2-hander would have, and if RDD is off the table, and if Terrifying Rage is disabled, and if Devcrit, as you say, is also disabled, then that's A LOT of crippling to start out with the Barbarian class and a 2-handed weapon. So, the first thing that you want to do when building a toon for a certain environment is finding out the specifics. In that sense, we already know that RDD isn't a possibility, so your next mission is to find the answers to each of the following questions:

1- Does Terrifying Rage work in Arelith?

2- Is there a way to obtain Shield-type AC to compensate for wielding a two-handed weapon?

As Val has said, both answers are probably no, but we need certainty, not probability.

Also, you need to start to understand the basic principles of Character Building for Neverwinter Nights. I wrote a very extensive guide for that here in the ECB. It's called "A Complete Guide to the Basics of Character Building" and you can find it in the Game Guides section. Basics in there refers not to basic as in beginning, but to basics as in base-principles, the foundation upon which Character Building is built. Please read it. It'll take time, but I expect you to have a good understanding of the following concepts after reading:

- BAB progressions and how to build-up BAB, the Rule of 4
- Skill Dumps, when to do them and how they work
- Epic Feats and Requirements: how to organize and prioritize them

OK, now you have a lot of work to do. I'll leave you to it.

Take it EZ!

Did some research after reading about paths, (I don't know anything abou them myself except for Kensai, and looking at the benefits its probably not worth itTribesman Instead of the normal barbarian rage ability the tribesman gets the ability to summon a tribal warrior for each rage. Only two can be called upon at the same time.
  • They act as henchmen, so a summoned creature can be conjured as well
  • They share race, sex and armour design of the player character. The armour design is what the player character has equipped when using the rage ability.
  • They share the Barbarian level (not character level) of the player character.
  • They DON'T share racial abilities with the Player character and they DON'T share any enchantments the player character has on their armour.
The Tribal Warrior has the following Ability scores at level 1: 16 Strength, 15 Dexterity, 14 Constitution and 10 Intelligencce, Charisma and Wisdom. Level 1 feats are: Ambidexterity, All Armour proficiencies, Rage, Fast Movement, Improved Two-Weapon Fighting, Power Attack, Shield Proficiency, Two-Weapon Fighting, Uncanny Dodge 1, Weapon Focii: Battleaxe, Handaxe, weapon prof: Martial, Simple Weapon Spec: Battleaxe, Handaxe.
(know nothing, probably not worth it ether.)KensaiMain article: KensaiKensai is a path selectable by Barbarians, Fighters, Monks and Rogues.A kensai gains:
  • Permanent haste (coupled with a speed reduction effect of -30%)
  • They are prevented from equipping any ranged weapons
  • Cannot use spells from any source, including feats that replicate the effects of spells.
  • +10 discipline.
(This one is probably not worth it, you get permanent haste. But, you also lose the power to use potions or anything magical (and I'm hearing that includes weapons and items with magical enhancments but don't hold me to that.)

Now to answer your questions in terms of Shield AC I'm not positive. I mean I know there are mechanics in the game that allow you to buff up an item for more AC, (Enhance it), but I don't know how far that truly goes.

Now onto the talk of Terrifying rage.

It seems to work on Arelith, the only thing they got rid of was Devastating Critical (Due to the possibility to one shot every time you crit.) As, from the research I did, thoroughly, I did not find any changes from said feat either.

posts.author: Maximillian Kane
posts.content:
Great, Jaquerez!

I see you did your homework. So, you don't want a Kensai, which is fine, my question is: do you HAVE TO choose one of these two paths?

If so, and you'll be forced to be a Tribesman, and the summons share your Barbarian level, then a near-pure Barbarian might be a good option there, do you agree so far? So, we can establish we want 24 Barbarian levels for Terrifying Rage and for the summons to be more potent, right? Why 24? Because Barbarians gain a Bonus Feat every 4 levels after 20, so in Arelith it's 24 and 28. 28 as we know is impossible because you can't take only 2 levels of a secondary class, so 24 is pretty much our only choice. We can afford 2 other classes, with 3 levels each, or 1 other class with 6 levels. Actually, find out for me please if the summons are any good at all. If they are, then we can have them, but if not, we can just drop barbarian levels way below 24 to be able to get more juice from other classes.

High level Barbarian characters gain Damage Reduction, which is cool, and even better if comboed with Epic Damage Reduction feats. That in a level 30 world means low AB, in a level 30 world without RDD, HELL NO! So we can keep CON with an average score.

The cool thing about Barbs is that they have access to Taunt and to Intimidate as class skills and they gain 4 skill points per level, but the shitty thing about Half-Orcs is that they have an INT penalty, and therefore lose 30 skill points, which are desirable. So, one way to fix that in Arelith is to go 18 STR 12 INT and put the two gifts in STR and INT, making them 20 and 14 (which will also have the good side effect of allowing you access to Expertise and Improved Knockdown (both of which need 13 INT).

Also, as Barbarians, we need Heavy Armor proficiency. We can get that from another class (such as Fighter or CoT) or waste a feat on it. I say we take a class that has it. Fighter seems to be the best option, as you'll also get two Bonus Feats with it. Unfortunately, you can't take Epic Weapon Specialization with only 3 levels, which is one of the desirable feats to have on a melee warrior. That's why it's important to see if the summons are worth the investment in Barbarian levels. Otherwise, we could easily stop Barbarian at 17 or even 16 and go for more Fighter.

Get back to me on this and we can continue building the toon. Right now we're DEFINING THE OPTIMAL SPREAD (reference to my Complete Guide that you need to read). We need to get this figured out so we can proceed any further.

Take it EZ!

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
That information is incorrect, Half-Orcs cannot wield a 2-handed weapon in one hand in Neverwinter Nights 1. That is only possible in NwN 2 with the aid of a feat called "Monkey Grip" that imparts a hefty penalty to the AB of your character.

For your character you should consider the Gift of Strength at least, CON Gift isn't as important if you are not making an EDR 3 character. But first as Max said you must decide what classes are the best for your build.

posts.author: Maximillian Kane
posts.content:
OK, Jaquerez, you're turning out a great student, bro! Keep up the good work!

So, if the summons are shit later on, we don't need to invest that much in Barbarian levels. That will give us A LOT of room to play with. We can keep Barbarian at 17 (15 pre-epic and 2 post-epic, one to get Terrifying Rage and another one at 30 to max out Taunt, Intimidate and Discipline), Fighter or CoT (depending on the answer you give to the question below) 10 and Rogue or Bard 3

Let me ask you a personal question: What do you prefer: to do more damage or to have higher saves? This will allow us to decide between CoT and Fighter. Fighter gives us Epic Weapon Specialization (and also one more feat), and CoT gives us +5 to all saves (and one less feat). Both give us same Armor and Martial proficiencies. So, what's more important to you?

Our third class should be taken for Skill Dumps on the main desireable skills, such as Tumble, UMD (Use Magic Device). The classes that get these skills are: Rogue, Bard and Assassin. Assassin, however, will require you to invest Skill Points in Hide / Move Silently, which are problem, because you already have many skills that you need to put points into: Discipline, Taunt, Tumble, UMD, Intimidate, and if you have spare, Concentration and Listen or Spot (to see hidden monsters, choose one, no need to waste skill points on both). Rogue will give us 2d6 Sneak Attack damage, Evasion and the skills. Bard will give us a mild Song bonus to attack an damage and Spellcraft as a class skill (which we may not have points to invest in, so not really that good). Evasion is very important to have, and Barbarians have bonus saves versus traps, which coupled with Evasion can allow you to avoid a lot of damage from traps. I would choose Rogue. However, since Arelith is pretty RP-heavy, it may be hard to RP Rogue into the build, while Bard could symbolize some sort of war cry. Tough to say, you know better than me.

So, we have pretty much defined our class split, we have defined that we'll take the gifts and screw ourselves to level him so he's strong. We need to just choose either Fighter or Champion of Torm and Rogue or Bard and then we can build him. I'll await your reply.

Take it EZ!

posts.author: Maximillian Kane
posts.content:
Hey brother!

Now, what you are saying has some logic to it, but it's not exactly how it works. Sometimes, your saves will be SO LOW (like this Barbarian's Will save), that even with the saves from CoT, you'll fail saves, depending on the DC. For these types of situation, Clarity Potions will save the day. All melee toons suffer from low saves, well, not all, but most. +5 to all saves may not be enough to avoid getting feared. You need to ask more experienced Arelith players about this, but it's a possibility, and you must be aware of it.

Here's a rough sketch of the build with your choices factored in. Since you said nothing about Bard or Rogue, I went with Rogue:

Barbarian(17), Champion of Torm(10), Rogue(3),

Half-Orc
STR: 22 (30)
DEX: 8
CON: 14
WIS: 8

Hey Jaquerez!

I built it that way considering you would be a Tribesman. The first 15 Barbarian levels, you'll use the summons, which should help you level up, after that, you'll still use them, but each new level and feat you acquire will let you will need less and less of them.

You should consider Valerfor's suggestions 1 and 2. We could trade Cleave for Iron Will pre-epic (which will require the delay of one combat feat, but it's not a big deal) and ESF: Discipline for Epic Will, which will increase your Will saves to 21, and has good Synergy with CoT saves bonuses. You'll be the judge of that. Think about what you know in Arelith and consider what would be more useful for you: +6 to Will saves or +10 to Discipline skill and Cleave? Your decision. His suggestions are good.

The third suggestion I don't consider so good, at least not to my playing experience. I have always liked Rogue over Bard as a skill dump class, especially for Evasion. Without it, you'll take damage from every trap you get caught on, and we all know Barbarians don't exactly excell at finding traps. Not just that, but rock-hurling giants will also KICK YOUR ASS. Also, there are other ways to boost your saves against spells (Protection from Spells scrolls, for example), but IDK if those are available in Arelith.

So, make any adjustments that you feel necessary and then we'll talk about what we did here and what we learned, yes?

Oh yes, and go to our section Tools for the Builder and download the CBC (Character Build Calculator). It's a FANTASTIC tool! I'll teach you how to use it.

posts.author: Maximillian Kane
posts.content:
OK, Jaquerez, to finish off this build, we're going to look at what we did, the hows and the whys and try to learn as much as we can from our choices (it's not the choices themselves that are important, but the thought process behind them).

So, the first thing we began with was a Half-orc Barbarian. Obviously, we weren't going to go Barbarian straight up to 30, but we needed to figure out exactly how many Barbarian levels we needed for our Build to achieve what we wanted. When going STR-based, one of the very desireable things we could take is Devcrit. That was banned, so off the table. RDD is also not there for us to give us AC and STR increases. Weapon Master would also be nice for critical hit enhancements, but requirements are too heavy, so we narrowed it down to Champion of Torm, which would give us extra feats, and Fighter, but Fighter would give us more damage, while CoT would give us Saves.

We also established that we didn't want to build for the summons, but for a Barbarian, we pretty much ALWAYS have to consider Terrifying Rage, which requires Greater Rage, which is attained at Barbarian level 15 (NWN Wiki is very useful to figure out requirements). We also found out that the summons are useful early on, but start becoming obsolete later on, so we decided to take the first 15 levels of Barbarian to make the most use of them and make our levelling easier. We couldn't go for EDR without jeopardizing out AB too much on a level 30 CAP server, so our CON didn't need to be raised much, and we didn't need to take many Barbarian levels for damage reduction points. That practically defined that we wouldn't need to go much over Barbarian 15. We chose 17 for 2 post-epic Taunt and Intimidate dumps, one at level 30 to max the skills out and one at level 24 to take Terrifying Rage at the earliest possible level (Terrifying Rage requires 25 Intimidate, which is only attainable at level 22. The earliest possible general feat level after 22 is 24, that's why we took Barbarian there). See, every choice has a reason behind it. Learning to prioritize is a vital skill to be a good builder.

Then we decided CoT would be our secondary class, granting us feats and save bonuses, and we also decided we'd need to save some CoT levels for epics to be able to take Epic Weapon Focus, Armor Skin and Epic Prowess with them, so we took 5 CoT levels before 20 (2 feats) and saved 5 (3 feats, one for each of the previously mentioned feats) for epics. We wanted to max out Tumble, so we took Rogue as a tertiary class at 25, 26 and 27 to respect the Rule of Arelith, and only 15 UMD cuz the place is low magic. The reason for taking Rogue at those levels is simple. We wanted MAX Tumble, and skill total maximum for a class skill is always Level +3, so in case we needed 27 levels to have 30 Ranks in Tumble.

Then we evaluated Valerfor's suggestions, which I thought were really valid, but in the end you decided not to heed them, using your server knowledge. However, we also learned even not taking his suggestions. He made us think about a possible way to enhance our will save after you expressed that concern. We thought about it, and in thinking, we learned.

We only needed 2 Rogue levels for Evasion, but that 3rd level was required by Arelith rules, and it also gave us +1d6 Sneak Attack damage (not that damage will be a problem for us). Our barbarian can scare the living crap out of everyone with his Terrifying Rage, he can summon some barbs to kick some ass with him while enemies are scared and he has really nice AB and a pretty good 1-handed damage. He will stay upright for sure in all fights with his Epic Skill Focus in Discipline, but he'll need to rely on immunities to avoid certain mental effects.

All in all, we've arrived at this final version, which is pretty cool, optimized and well thought out. All the levels that we ended on give us something: Barbarian 17 gives us +1 Damage Reduction (not much, but it's something!), CoT 10 gives us a Bonus Feat and Rogue 3 gave us +1d6 Sneak Attack damage. We did good!

OH, one more thing! About the remaining skill points, no you won't save them for never LOL. Just allocate them as you see fit. The only thing that I need to warn tou about is that you need to do so after level 27, because you only have 1 single skill point left after you take all the stuff from the Rogue levels. Then it builds up again. So, spend them in anything you see fit, just after 27th level.
